content: The "Citizens' Right to Know Act of 1999" requires disclosure of information. The "Citizens' Right to Know Act of 1999" mandates political committees to disclose contributions and expenditures of $200 or more on the Internet within 14 days of receiving or making them. The "Citizens' Right to Know Act of 1999" requires political committees to disclose contributions and expenditures of $200 or more within 14 days on the Internet. Information cannot be sold or used for soliciting contributions, except for using the name and address of a political committee for solicitation. Candidates must disclose within 14 days starting 18 months before the general election. The "Citizens' Right to Know Act of 1999" mandates disclosure of contributions and expenditures over $200 within 14 days on the Internet. Candidates must disclose within 14 days starting 18 months before the general election, covering the election cycle for the office they are seeking. The "Citizens' Right to Know Act of 1999" requires disclosure of contributions and expenditures over $200 within 14 days online. Candidates must disclose within 14 days starting 18 months before the general election, covering the election cycle for the office they are seeking. Amendments are made to the Federal Election Campaign Act and the Communications Act regarding political committees and broadcasting records. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a requirement for licensees or cable system operators to maintain and make available a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to federal elections or candidates. Licensees or cable system operators must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for federal elections. The record includes whether the request is accepted or rejected, the rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, and details of the candidate or political party. This information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained by the licensee. Licensees or cable system operators must retain records of broadcast time purchase requests for federal elections for at least 2 years. SEC. 3. MODIFICATION OF CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are modified as follows: Candidate limit increased from $1,000 to $5,000, party limits raised to $50,000, and state party limit adjusted with additional conditions. The contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are modified to increase candidate limits to $5,000, raise party limits to $50,000, and adjust state party limits with additional conditions, including contributions to a political committee established by a State party exceeding $15,000 in a calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase candidate limits to $5,000, raise party limits to $50,000, and set additional conditions for state party limits, including contributions exceeding $15,000 to a political committee established by a State party in a calendar year. Individual contribution limits are also adjusted to $50,000 for subparagraphs (A) and (C) of paragraph (1) and subparagraphs (B) and (D) of paragraph (1). SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES OF POLITICAL COMMITTEES. The definition of Contribution and Expenditure under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include amounts received by political party committees for legal or accounting services and costs related to compliance with the Act or the Internal Revenue Code. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include payment by political party committees for legal or accounting services and compliance costs, such as electronic recordkeeping. SEC. 4. TAX DEDUCTION FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO CERTAIN POLITICAL COMMITTEES AND CANDIDATES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow tax deductions for political contributions. Tax deduction allowed for qualified political contributions made by individuals, limited to $100 ($200 for joint returns). Qualified political contributions include payments to candidates, political party committees, and qualified political committees. The text chunk discusses the definition of a political committee as a separate segregated fund maintained by certain entities and certified by the Federal Election Commission. The credit for contributions is allowed only if verified as prescribed by the Secretary. Other terms like 'authorized committee', 'candidate', 'contribution', and 'political committee' are defined as per section 301 of the Act. The text chunk amends the voluntary disclosure requirement in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 by adding a new section. The text chunk introduces a new section, SEC. 324, regarding the voluntary disclosure requirement in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 324 introduces the option for organizations with segregated funds to disclose political activity disbursements by filing an annual report with the Commission. Political activity includes voter registration, get-out-the-vote efforts, direct mail campaigns, advertising, and polling. The report must be submitted annually in a specified format. The Commission requires organizations with segregated funds to file an annual report by September 1 containing necessary information related to political activity disbursements. The report must be made accessible to the public by September 30, and a list of reporting organizations is also published. Additionally, the Commission certifies organizations for political contributions by September 30 each year. The Commission certifies organizations for political contributions by September 30 each year, and lists reporting organizations for public access. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section regarding political contributions and personal services in coordination with a political committee will apply to taxable years beginning after the date of enactment of this Act.
